Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I stared at my phone, reading Mia’s last message over and over. She was upset that I hadn’t told her about my church plans for Sunday, and now she thought I was avoiding spending time with her. As her boyfriend, I knew I should call her, talk things through, and make sure she felt heard. We’d always promised to resolve conflicts quickly, never letting small misunderstandings fester. But Sunday was also the day of our church’s monthly outreach, and as a committed Christian, I was expected to be there—not just for the service, but to help with the community lunch afterward. My pastor had reminded us last week how important it was to show up, to be present for each other and for those we served. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing down on me: Mia needed me to prioritize our relationship, but my faith community needed me, too. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be both the boyfriend she deserved and the Christian I wanted to be.
